facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 193 of 1961 in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 193 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated February 9 and 10, 1961 of Gujarat High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 367 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 9 and 10, 1961, of the Gujarat High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 367 of 1960.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on December 6, 1963 by Sarkar J.

anchor.surface_text: December 6, 1963. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by 1/SC1/64-51 SARKAR J.-This appeal raises a question under the Fact

facts.text: Respondent is the Manager of an oil mill.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is the Manager of an oil mill. The mill had a spur gear wheel.

facts.text: Mill had a spur gear wheel.

anchor.surface_text: The mill had a spur gear wheel. A workman of the mill while greasing the spur gear wheel which was then in motion

facts.text: Workman of the mill while greasing the spur gear wheel in motion had one hand caught and amputated.

anchor.surface_text: A workman of the mill while greasing the spur gear wheel which was then in motion had one of his hands caught in it. Eventually that hand had to be amputated.

facts.text: Spur gear wheel had a cover which had bolts for fixing it to the base but at time of accident the cover was not there, having been removed earlier.

anchor.surface_text: It appeared that the spur gear wheel bad a companyer which had bolts for fixing it to the base but at the time of the accident the companyer was number there, having apparently been removed earlier.

facts.text: No evidence to show when the cover was last in position.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberevidence to show when it was last in position. The respondent was prosecuted under s. 92 of the Act

facts.text: Respondent prosecuted under s.92 of the Factories Act, 1948 for failing to comply with s.21(1)(iv)(c).

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was prosecuted under s. 92 of the Act for having failed to, companyply with s. 21 1   iv   c .

facts.text: Guard had been put over the spur gear wheel and it was a proper guard.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute that a guard had been put over the spur gear wheel and it was a proper guard.

facts.text: If guard had been there, respondent would not have committed offence.

anchor.surface_text: It is number companytended that if it had been there, then the respondent companyld be said. to have companymitted any offence,

facts.text: Guard was not there at the time of accident.

anchor.surface_text: but it was number there. The workman said that it had been removed by the respondent for repairs

facts.text: Workman said guard removed by respondent for repairs.

anchor.surface_text: The workman said that it had been removed by the respondent for repairs while the case of the respondent

facts.text: Respondent's case: workman had himself removed the guard.

anchor.surface_text: while the case of the respondent was that the workman had himself removed it.

facts.text: Learned trial Judge unable to accept either version and acquitted respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial Judge was unable to accept either version and he acquitted the respondent observing that he companyld number be held liable if the companyer was removed by someone without his companysent or knowledge.

facts.text: Gujarat High Court in appeal referred to cases and deduced two principles on foreseeability and unreasonable act of workman.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court when the matter came to them in appeal, referred to a very large number of cases... If the Safeguard provided by the employer or manager is rendered nugatory by an unreasonable or perverted act on the part of the workman, there is numberliability of the employer or manager.

facts.text: Supreme Court unable to appreciate relevancy of High Court principles.

anchor.surface_text: With great respect to the learned Judges of the High Court we are unable to appreciate the relevancy of these two principles to the decision of the case in hand.

facts.text: No dispute that spur gear wheel was dangerous machine within s.21(1)(iv)(c).

anchor.surface_text: As the High Court stated, there is numberdispute that the spur gear wheel was a dangerous machine within the meaning of s. 21 1  iv  c .

facts.text: Respondent had provided the guard over the machine.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed the fact that the respondent had provided the guard over the machine puts it beyond doubt,

facts.text: High Court proceeded on assumption that not proved workman removed guard; Supreme Court also proceeds on that assumption.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court proceeded on the assumption that it had number been proved that the workman had himself removed the guard. We will also proceed on that assumption.

facts.text: Respondent gave no evidence to show what he had done to carry out duty to keep guard in position.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent has given numberevidence whatever to show what he had done to carry out his duty to see that the guard was kept in position when the machine was working.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal, sets aside judgments of courts below, convicts respondent under s.92 for contravening s.21(1)(iv)(c), imposes fine of Rs.200.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly we allow the appeal and set aside the judgment of the Courts below and companyvict the respondent under s. 92 for companytravening the terms of S. 21 1  iv  c . We impose on him a fine of Rs.200.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 9 and 10, 1961, of the Gujarat High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 367 of 1960.
The respondent was prosecuted under s. 92 of the Act for having failed to, companyply with s. 21 1   iv   c . The relevant part of this section is as follows

concepts.unlisted_description: Punishment for contravention of Act provisions; occupier or manager guilty of offence punishable with imprisonment or fine

anchor.surface_text: S. 21.  1  In every factory the following namely,- unless they are in such position or of such companystruction as to be safe to every person employed in the factory as they would be if they were securely fenced, the following, namely-  c  every dangerous part of any other machinery, shall be securely fenced by safeguards of substantial companystruction which shall be kept in position while the parts of machinery they are fencing are in motion or in use

concepts.unlisted_description: Dangerous parts of machinery to be securely fenced by safeguards kept in position while in motion

anchor.surface_text: Section 92 of the Act provides as follows S. 92. anchor.surface_text: Section 101 of the Act was referred to as supporting the companytention that the liability of an occupier or manager for failure to observe the terms of the Act was absolute and the only defence available to him was that provided by it. ... The section states that where an occupier or manager of a factory is charged with an offence punishable under this Act, he shall be entitled to have any other person whom he charges as the actual offender brought before the Court and if he proves to the satisfaction of the Court  a  that he used due diligence to enforce the execution of the Act, and  b  that the said other person companymitted the offence in question without his knowledge, companysent or companynivance, then that other person shall be companyvicted of the offence and the occupier or the manager shall be discharged.

issues.text: Whether there is no liability if the safeguard is rendered nugatory by an unreasonable or perverted act on the part of the workman

anchor.surface_text: If the Safeguard provided by the employer or manager is rendered nugatory by an unreasonable or perverted act on the part of the workman, there is numberliability of the employer or manager.

anchor.surface_text: Does the mere fact that someone else had removed the safeguard without the knowledge, companysent of companynivance of the occupier or manager always provide a defence to him? We do number think so.

arguments.claim: s.21(1)(iv)(c) requires safeguards to be kept in position while machinery in motion; fencing suggests always there; default occurred as not there when working

anchor.surface_text: No doubt the default on the part of the person accused has to be established by the prosecution before there can be a conviction. It has to be observed that s. 21  1  iv  c  requires not only that the dangerous part of a machine shall be securely fenced by safeguards but also that the safeguards shall be kept in position while the parts of the machinery they are fencing are in motion or in use.

arguments.claim: Mere removal of safeguard by someone else without knowledge consent or connivance does not always provide defence to occupier or manager

anchor.surface_text: Does the mere fact that someone else had removed the safeguard without the knowledge, consent of connivance of the occupier or manager always provide a defence to him? We do not think so.

arguments.claim: When guard not kept in position while machine working, onus on accused to establish not liable

anchor.surface_text: When the statute says that it will be his duty to keep the guard in position when the machine is working and when it appears that he has not done so, it will be for him to establish that notwithstanding this he was not liable.

arguments.claim: Not liable in every case of removal e.g. if fence suddenly breaks down without responsibility

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary for us to say that in every case where it is proved that the manager or occupier had provided the necessary fence or guard but at a particular moment it appeared that the fence or guard had been removed, he must be held liable.

arguments.qualifiers: It is not necessary for us to say

anchor.surface_text: A statute does not, of course, require an impossibility of a person.

arguments.claim: Respondent gave no evidence of what done to carry out duty to keep guard in position

anchor.surface_text: The respondent has given no evidence whatever to show what he had done to carry out his duty to see that the guard was kept in position when the machine was working.

arguments.claim: Under s.101 defence requires proof of due diligence to enforce Act even if other person committed without knowledge consent connivance; due diligence includes ensuring fence kept in position

anchor.surface_text: The section states that where an occupier or manager of a factory is charged with an offence punishable under this Act, he shall be entitled to have any other person whom he charges as the actual offender brought before the Court and if he proves to the satisfaction of the Court a that he used due diligence to enforce the execution of the Act, and b that the said other person committed the offence in question without his knowledge, consent or connivance

arguments.claim: Duty to exercise due diligence applies even if cannot identify who removed fence

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us clear that if it was his duty to exercise due diligence for the purpose in a case where he could establish that somebody else had removed the fence, it would be equally his duty to exercise that diligence where he could not prove who had removed it.

arguments.claim: Not providing due diligence defence where offender unidentified would defeat Act's intention to protect workmen

anchor.surface_text: If it were not so, the intention of the Act to give protection to workmen would be wholly defeated.

holdings.text: convict the respondent under s. 92 for contravening the terms of S. 21 1  iv  c

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly we allow the appeal and set aside the judgment of the Courts below and convict the respondent under s. 92 for contravening the terms of S. 21 1  iv  c . We impose on him a fine of Rs.200.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Default admitted as guard absent during operation; respondent adduced no evidence of measures to ensure guard kept in position or due diligence under s.101; failed to discharge onus.

holdings.text: We are unable to appreciate the relevancy of these two principles to the decision of the case in hand

anchor.surface_text: With great respect to the learned Judges of the High Court we are unable to appreciate the relevancy of these two principles to the decision of the case in hand.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court deduced foreseeability and unreasonable workman act principles but did not rest judgment on them; unnecessary to discuss.

holdings.text: s. 21 1 iv c requires not only that the dangerous part of a machine shall be securely fenced by safeguards but also that the safeguards shall be kept in position while the parts of the machinery they are fencing are in motion or in use

anchor.surface_text: No doubt the default on the part of the person accused has to be established by the prosecution before there can be a conviction. It has to be observed that s. 21  1  iv  c  requires not only that the dangerous part of a machine shall be securely fenced by safeguards but also that the safeguards shall be kept in position while the parts of the machinery they are fencing are in motion or in use.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory text imposes ongoing duty to maintain safeguards in position during machine operation; default occurred as guard absent when working.

holdings.text: Does the mere fact that someone else had removed the safeguard without the knowledge, consent of connivance of the occupier or manager always provide a defence to him? We do not think so

anchor.surface_text: Does the mere fact that someone else had removed the safeguard without the knowledge, consent of connivance of the occupier or manager always provide a defence to him? We do not think so.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statute imposes duty to keep guard in position; mere third-party removal without knowledge/consent/connivance insufficient defence without more.

holdings.text: When the statute says that it will be his duty to keep the guard in position when the machine is working and when it appears that he has not done so, it will be for him to establish that notwithstanding this he was not liable

anchor.surface_text: When the statute says that it will be his duty to keep the guard in position when the machine is working and when it appears that he has not done so, it will be for him to establish that notwithstanding this he was not liable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution proves default; onus shifts to accused to prove non-liability despite default.

holdings.text: It is not necessary for us to say that in every case where it is proved that the manager or occupier had provided the necessary fence or guard but at a particular moment it appeared that the fence or guard had been removed, he must be held liable. [...] A statute does not, of course, require an impossibility of a person

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary for us to say that in every case where it is proved that the manager or occupier had provided the necessary fence or guard but at a particular moment it appeared that the fence or guard had been removed, he must be held liable. Suppose the fence for some reason for which the manager or occupier is not responsible, suddenly breaks down and the machine remains unfenced for sometime before the owner or occupier found that out and replaced the fence. It may be that in such a case he cannot be made liable. A statute does not, of course, require an impossibility of a person.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical sudden breakdown without fault may excuse; statute demands no impossibility (not applicable here).

holdings.text: even where the occupier or manager proves that somebody else has removed the fencing without his knowledge, consent or connivance, that alone would not exempt him from liability but he has further to prove that he had used due diligence to enforce the execution of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The section states that where an occupier or manager of a factory is charged with an offence punishable under this Act, he shall be entitled to have any other person whom he charges as the actual offender brought before the Court and if he proves to the satisfaction of the Court  a  that he used due diligence to enforce the execution of the Act, and  b  that the said other person committed the offence in question without his knowledge, consent or connivance, then that other person shall be convicted of the offence and the occupier or the manager shall be discharged. It will appear, therefore, that even where the occupier or manager proves that somebody else has removed the fencing without his knowledge, consent or connivance, that alone would not exempt him from liability but he has further to prove that he had used due diligence to enforce the execution of the Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.101 text requires both due diligence and lack of knowledge/consent/connivance for discharge.

holdings.text: if it was his duty to exercise due diligence for the purpose in a case where he could establish that somebody else had removed the fence, it would be equally his duty to exercise that diligence where he could not prove who had removed it

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us clear that if it was his duty to exercise due diligence for the purpose in a case where he could establish that somebody else had removed the fence, it would be equally his duty to exercise that diligence where he could not prove who had removed it. If it were not so, the intention of the Act to give protection to workmen would be wholly defeated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Due diligence obligation under s.101 extends to unidentified offenders; otherwise defeats worker protection purpose.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly we allow the appeal and set aside the judgment of the Courts below and convict the respondent under s. 92 for contravening the terms of S. 21 1  iv  c . We impose on him a fine of Rs.200.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed, judgments of courts below set aside, respondent convicted under s.92 for contravening s.21(1)(iv)(c), fined Rs.200

anchor.surface_text: No doubt the default on the part of the person accused has to be established by the prosecution before there can be a conviction. It has to be observed that s. 21  1  iv  c  requires not only that the dangerous part of a machine shall be securely fenced by safeguards but also that the safeguards shall be kept in position while the parts of the machinery they are fencing are in motion or in use.

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary for us to say that in every case where it is proved that the manager or occupier had provided the necessary fence or guard but at a particular moment it appeared that the fence or guard had been removed, he must be held liable. Suppose the fence for some reason for which the manager or occupier is not responsible, suddenly breaks down and the machine remains unfenced for sometime before the owner or occupier found that out and replaced the fence. It may be that in such a case he cannot be made liable. A statute does not, of course, require an impossibility of a person.
fered numberdefence whatever, whether under s. 101 or otherwise. His only point was that he did number know what happened to the guard and that, in ou

anchor.surface_text: fered numberdefence whatever, whether under s. 101 or otherwise. His only point was that he did number know what happened to the guard and that, in ou

edges.explanation: Holding states proof of removal without knowledge does not exempt, addressing need for due diligence proof

anchor.surface_text: The section states that where an occupier or manager of a factory is charged with an offence punishable under this Act, he shall be entitled to have any other person whom he charges as the actual offender brought before the Court and if he proves to the satisfaction of the Court  a  that he used due diligence to enforce the execution of the Act, and  b  that the said other person committed the offence in question without his knowledge, consent or connivance, then that other person shall be convicted of the offence and the occupier or the manager shall be discharged. It will appear, therefore, that even where the occupier or manager proves that somebody else has removed the fencing without his knowledge, consent or connivance, that alone would not exempt him from liability but he has further to prove that he had used due diligence to enforce the execution of the Act
Accordingly we allow the appeal and set aside the judgment of the Courts below and convict the respondent under s. 92 for contravening the terms of S. 21 1  iv  c . We impose on him a fine of Rs.200.
t, that he exercised due diligence to see that the fence which under the Act it was his duty to see was kept in position all along had number been rem

edges.explanation: Due diligence duty holding supports ultimate conviction under s.92

anchor.surface_text: t, that he exercised due diligence to see that the fence which under the Act it was his duty to see was kept in position all along had number been rem

edges.explanation: Holding affirms duty of due diligence even without identifying remover, directly addressing the issue

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us clear that if it was his duty to exercise due diligence for the purpose in a case where he could establish that somebody else had removed the fence, it would be equally his duty to exercise that diligence where he could not prove who had removed it. If it were not so, the intention of the Act to give protection to workmen would be wholly defeated.
Accordingly we allow the appeal and set aside the judgment of the Courts below and convict the respondent under s. 92 for contravening the terms of S. 21 1  iv  c . We impose on him a fine of Rs.200.
